word.entryDescription: a member of a sports team who is supposed to move forward and try to score points
word.entryExample: Mr Malcolm read out the names of the attackers.

word.entryDescription: to go to school, college, etc
word.entryExample: When most people attend Glasto they stay in hotels.

word.entryDescription: a person who assists, guides or provides service for others
word.entryExample: After we had taken off, the flight attendants served drinks.

word.entryDescription: a space in a building just below the roof, often used for storing things and sometimes converted into a room; loft
word.entryExample: My room is in the attic.

word.entryDescription: the way you think or feel about someone or something, or they way you behave because of this
word.entryExample: A hard-working disposition and can-do attitude are a must.

word.entryDescription: appealing in appearance, or appealing in other ways
word.entryExample: Well, this attractive woman you are staring at is actually my mother.

word.entryDescription: a quality, characteristic feature of somebody/something
word.entryExample: How would you describe the attributes of a good doctor?

word.entryDescription: a group of people who watch or listen to a performance or a speaker
word.entryExample: The noise from the audience was so loud that the dancers couldn't hear the orchestra.

word.entryDescription: your mother or father's sister, or their brother's wife
word.entryExample: My aunt lives in the next street.

word.entryDescription: a very large island between the Indian Ocean and the southern Pacific Ocean, which is both a country and a continent
word.entryExample: Kangaroos come from Australia.

word.entryDescription: a car
word.entryExample: The Jaguar E-type is a beautiful automobile.

word.entryDescription: able to be used, bought, found
word.entryExample: Bicycles are available to hire in my town.

word.entryDescription: a mass of snow, ice, mud and rock falling down the side of a mountain
word.entryExample: Luckily, we weren't very close to the avalanche.

word.entryDescription: with a typical or ordinary appearance
word.entryExample: Barry is an average looking young man – medium height and medium build.

word.entryDescription: to stay away from someone or something, usually deliberately
word.entryExample: If I walked to school, I'd avoid the traffic jams.

word.entryDescription: a prize in a game, competition, etc
word.entryExample: Sam won an award because of his exam results.

word.entryDescription: knowing, understanding or noticing something
word.entryExample: Nowadays, more people are aware of ethical issues in fashion.

word.entryDescription: to or in a different place than
word.entryExample: It is in a quiet part of town, away from the noisy centre of Dahab.

word.entryDescription: an informal word that means you think something is very good
word.entryExample: That's awesome!

word.entryDescription: very bad
word.entryExample: The destruction from the tsunami was absolutely awful.

word.entryDescription: causing embarrassment, problems or discomfort
word.entryExample: There was an awkward moment when nobody could think of what to say.

word.entryDescription: a very young child who cannot walk or talk yet
word.entryExample: We have a new baby sister.

word.entryDescription: to take care of children or babies while their parents are out
word.entryExample: Kerry has come to Mrs Davies's house to babysit.

word.entryDescription: somebody who looks after children while their parents are out, and is usually paid for doing this
word.entryExample: Wanted: babysitter for 10-year-old boy and 8-year-old girl.

word.entryDescription: the top half of your body that is behind your chest
word.entryExample: I sleep on my back.

word.entryDescription: to admit that you are wrong, to take back a demand, an opinion, etc
word.entryExample: I know you want to back down, but try to stand up to them.

word.entryDescription: to decide not to do something that you had previously decided to do
word.entryExample: It's too late. You can't back out now.

word.entryDescription: to make a copy in order not to lose data if something goes wrong with a computer
word.entryExample: I had to back up the file to make sure it didn't disappear again.

word.entryDescription: a plan that can be used if a previous plan doesn't work out
word.entryExample: Do we have a back-up plan if we don't get tickets to the concert?

word.entryDescription: a pain in your back
word.entryExample: I need a new bed because the old one gives me backache.

word.entryDescription: the area of a picture behind the main subject
word.entryExample: There is a forest in the background.

word.entryDescription: a strong negative reaction to a trend or event
word.entryExample: Getting ‘back to nature’ and using locally grown organic food, is a backlash against modern food technology.

word.entryDescription: a small area with a hard surface behind a house
word.entryExample: The California dream is to have your own property with a frontyard and backyard and a 2-car garage.

word.entryDescription: plural of 'bacterium' – one of a group of tiny single-cell organisms, some of which can cause disease
word.entryExample: Bacteria multiply slower in low temperatures.

word.entryDescription: not good or of poor quality
word.entryExample: Yesterday was a bad day.

word.entryDescription: easily annoyed, in an angry mood
word.entryExample: She's terrible – bossy and bad-tempered.

word.entryDescription: a small sign you pin on your clothes containing words or a picture
word.entryExample: My school badge has the name of the school on it.

word.entryDescription: not done well
word.entryExample: Number 12 kicks the ball badly.

word.entryDescription: a sport two people play with rackets. You hit a light object over a high net on a court
word.entryExample: Badminton is a fun game.

word.entryDescription: something which you can put things in and carry from one place to another
word.entryExample: I carry my books to school in a bag.

word.entryDescription: the place at an airport where you pick up your luggage after you arrive
word.entryExample: You have to wait for your suitcase in the baggage reclaim.

word.entryDescription: used to describe clothes that are very loose or too big
word.entryExample: My brother doesn't like tight tops, so he usually wears a baggy jumper.

word.entryDescription: to cook in the oven, especially bread and cakes
word.entryExample: I'm going to bake some chocolate biscuits.

word.entryDescription: cooked in the oven
word.entryExample: Then, heat up the baked beans.

word.entryDescription: arranged to include different things or parts of something in either equal or correct amounts
word.entryExample: You need to eat plenty vegetables for a balanced diet.

word.entryDescription: a small outside area joined to a room in a flat
word.entryExample: I like to sit on the balcony and drink tea.

word.entryDescription: a round object that you throw, carry, kick or hit in sport
word.entryExample: Let's play with the ball.

word.entryDescription: a boy who picks up the balls for the players during important matches of e.g. tennis
word.entryExample: Ball boys were first introduced at Wimbledon in 1920.

word.entryDescription: a dance performance in which the dancers often stand on their toes
word.entryExample: My sister would choose going to a ballet. I would hate that.

word.entryDescription: a large round bag filled with hot air or gas which floats in the air and can carry people in a basket below it
word.entryExample: Has she travelled around the world in a balloon?
